description: Borrowed from Middle French persécuter, from Ecclesiastical Latin persecutor, from Latin persequor, persecutus (“follow up, pursue”), from per- (“through”) +‎ sequor (“follow”) (English sequel). Compare prosecute. Cf. also pursue.

verbs.description: persecute (third-person singular simple present persecutes, present participle persecuting, simple past and past participle persecuted)

entries.meaning: To pursue in a manner to do harm or cruelty to; especially,   because of the victim's race, sexual identity, or adherence to a particular belief.
examples: He who persecutes one will persecute all.

entries.meaning: To harass with importunity; to pursue with persistent solicitations; to annoy.
To kill many of one species of animal, with the intent of removing them from human habitats.
examples: Humans have been persecuting wolves in this forest for centuries.
